Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218,.proposition: 3. This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218, Section 21, as the subject matter of this action arises from a landlord-tenant dispute within the jurisdiction of this Court.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186,.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.

Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999),.raw_text: Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999), 56 Mass. App. Ct. 382
Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999),.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999),.case_name: Szymanski v. Boston Mutual Life Insurance
Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999),.support_reasoning: The opinion reproduced is not Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill at all, but a Massachusetts Appeals Court case involving misrepresentations in the sale of a “vanishing‑premiums” life insurance policy and statute‑of‑limitations/discovery‑rule issues. It does not concern landlord‑tenant law, residential tenancies, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address construction noise, dust, or interference with use of premises. Accordingly, it provides no authority for a claim of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on construction‑related disturbances.
Cambridge Housing Auth. v. Gill (1999),.relevant_excerpt: “At issue is the defendant insurer’s promotional materials and representations made by its insurance agent indicating that a so-called ‘vanishing-premiums’ life insurance policy sold to the plaintiff would accumulate sufficient value in nine years to cover the cost of the annual premiums thereafter… A judge of the Superior Court allowed the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the basis of statutes of limitations. We reverse.”

Greenleaf v. Cusack (1988), 23 Mass. App.raw_text: Greenleaf v. Cusack (1988), 23 Mass. App. Ct. 487
Greenleaf v. Cusack (1988), 23 Mass. App.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
Greenleaf v. Cusack (1988), 23 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns evidentiary limits on cross-examination about a complainant’s prior allegedly false accusations in a criminal sexual-assault prosecution. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, construction noise, dust, or interference with use of leased premises. Accordingly, it provides no authority for a civil claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Greenleaf v. Cusack (1988), 23 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted on indictments for natural and unnatural sexual intercourse with a child. The defendant is the former husband of the child’s mother. Citing Commonwealth v. Bohannon… he claims error in the refusal of the trial judge to permit him to cross-examine the victim about two allegedly false accusations made by her against others. We affirm.

Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge v. Cambrid.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge v. Cambrid.case_name: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. v. Board of Assessors of Everett
Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge v. Cambrid.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the local taxation of a cable television company’s personal property and interprets Massachusetts tax statutes on whether cables and converters are taxable. It does not involve landlord-tenant relationships, covenants of quiet enjoyment, construction noise, or interference with use of leased premises. Therefore, it provides no authority for a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on construction-related disturbances.
Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge v. Cambrid.relevant_excerpt: These cross appeals arise out of a decision of the Appellate Tax Board (board) on appeals to it by Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. (Warner) of local tax assessments made by the assessors of Everett for fiscal years 1980 and 1981 on personal property contained in Warner’s cable television system. We agree with Warner, on its appeal from the board’s decision, that its cables over public ways are not subject to local taxation, but we reject Warner’s argument that converters placed in subscribers’ homes are also free from local taxation.

Patterson v. Stewart Engineering Co. (19.raw_text: Patterson v. Stewart Engineering Co. (1986), 403 Mass. 679
Patterson v. Stewart Engineering Co. (19.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
Patterson v. Stewart Engineering Co. (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns a criminal prosecution for use of a steel jaw leghold trap under a wildlife statute, G. L. c. 131, § 80A, and addresses statutory interpretation and procedural issues regarding a motion to dismiss. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or issues of construction noise or interference with residential enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in a landlord-tenant context.
Patterson v. Stewart Engineering Co. (19.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant was charged in the Orange Division of the District Court Department with using a 'steel jaw leghold trap' in violation of G. L. c. 131, § 80A (1986 ed.).... In determining the type of traps prohibited by the phrase 'steel jaw leghold trap' we must not regard any of the statute’s words as superfluous..."

King v. Welford (2004), 57 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: King v. Welford (2004), 57 Mass. App. Ct. 768
King v. Welford (2004), 57 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
King v. Welford (2004), 57 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in King v. Welford does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or interference with use of premises. It is a juvenile delinquency case concerning sufficiency of evidence for larceny of a motor vehicle, addressing criminal standards of proof and circumstantial evidence. It therefore provides no authority for a civil claim of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on construction noise or dust.
King v. Welford (2004), 57 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "On September 10, 2001, Prentice R, a juvenile, was charged in the Juvenile Court Department, Brockton Division, with larceny of a motor vehicle, malicious damage to a motor vehicle, possession of a burglarious tool, and resisting arrest… On this record the Commonwealth’s proof was insufficient to show, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the juvenile stole the motor vehicle."

McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. C.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. Ct. 136
McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. C.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. C.case_name: APT Asset Management, Inc. v. Board of Appeals
McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The case is a zoning/land-use decision about whether an assisted living residence is a permitted use in a particular zoning district. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, residential leases, or any discussion of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, construction noise, dust, or interference with a tenant’s use of premises. Therefore it provides no authority for a quiet enjoyment claim under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and is mis-cited for that proposition.
McKenna v. Begin (1998), 50 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “While APT concedes that G. L. c. 19D and the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto ‘create a legal status between APT and each resident that is different from the legal relationship of the average landlord with the average tenant,’ it makes the final argument that the Land Court judge improperly focused upon that relationship rather than upon the actual proposed residential use of the property.… In our view, the nature and extent of these services constitute a change in the use of the property.”

Malinoski v. Duntley (2001), 60 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Malinoski v. Duntley (2001), 60 Mass. App. Ct. 774
Malinoski v. Duntley (2001), 60 Mass. Ap.proposition: 10. Plaintiff asserts a single cause of action against Defendant for Breach of the Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment, based on the ongoing and excessive noise from construction, dust infiltration, and resultant interference with Plaintiff's peaceful enjoyment of the premises, in violation of Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws and applicable case law.
Malinoski v. Duntley (2001), 60 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal larceny case about sufficiency of evidence and intent to steal in contractor–customer transactions. It does not involve landlord–tenant relationships, covenants of quiet enjoyment, construction noise, dust, or interference with use of leased premises. Therefore it provides no authority for a civil claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.
Malinoski v. Duntley (2001), 60 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: Turning to the evidence presented at trial on Mazza’s complaint against the defendant, we conclude that the Commonwealth’s evidence on this complaint was also insufficient to show the defendant’s intent with respect to the money he received from her on August 3, or that they had a relationship of trust and confidence... Proof that allows for no more than speculation requires that a defendant’s motion for a required finding of not guilty be allowed.
